Topic.Title: Romney paid just 13% in taxes last year

Message.Msg: No, Fruitloop, in point of fact Romney does not: FICA tax is not assessed on income from capital gains. Nor (as of this writing) is Medicare tax assessed on income from capital gains. (Even if they WERE assessed on capital gains INCOME, this would no doubt be limited to "realized" capital gains income, which for the Romneys of the world can often be limited to a teeny, tiny fraction of their TOTAL capital gains INCOME.) Only wage slaves have traditionally been expected to pay these, which combined equal 15.3% for the vast majority of Americans (and on the very first dollar earned), as I previously noted. And 15.3% is (still, as of this writing) LARGER than 14%. You're just so #$%$ stupid, I lose IQ points every time I read one of your posts. Hard to believe you remember to breathe.

Message.Title: why is Mitt different then every other candidate?
Message.Msg: "This whole issue is not about me," Reid said in his home state of Nevada on Monday. "Mitt Romney's the first presidential candidate since his dad ran not to release his income tax returns. He's released one income tax return, and that points toward the Bahamas, Switzerland and a few other foreign countries. This whole controversy will end very quickly if he releases his income tax returns, like everybody else has done." Romney has released his tax return from 2010 and an estimate from 2011. He has vowed to release his full 2011 return once it's completed, but he will not release past years', as previous presidential candidates have done. Meanwhile, Reid chief of staff David Krone insisted Monday, again, that he knows who Reid's source is -- and that the source is credible. "I know who this person is, and if I thought this person was not credible, I would say something to Sen. Reid. I would try to shut it down. This person is credible," Krone said. "This person has asked Reid to protect the confidentiality of this person, but it's real," he continued. "This person told him this. This person said it to Sen. Reid."

Message.Title: the obvious solution from a republican
Message.Msg: STOCKMAN: The Ryan budget is a ‘fairy tale,’ not a serious vision. ”Paul D. Ryan is the most articulate and intellectually imposing Republican of the moment, but that doesn’t alter the fact that this earnest congressman from Wisconsin is preaching the same empty conservative sermon…A true agenda to reform the welfare state would require a sweeping, income-based eligibility test, which would reduce or eliminate social insurance benefits for millions of affluent retirees. Without it, there is no math that can avoid giant tax increases or vast new borrowing. Yet the supposedly courageous Ryan plan would not cut one dime over the next decade from the $1.3 trillion-per-year cost of Social Security and Medicare. Instead, it shreds the measly means-tested safety net for the vulnerable…In short, Mr. Ryan’s plan is devoid of credible math or hard policy choices.” David A. Stockman in The New York Times.

Topic.Title: GOP PROS FUME: Romney Ceded Election With Ryan Pick

Message.Msg: Mitt nominated an extremist the baggers love him but everyone else hates him there is no compromise with Ryan just a fiscal cliff Representative Paul Ryan was a pivotal figure in killing the 2010 Bowles-Simpson agreement, which Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney now holds out as a model for putting America’s fiscal house in order. The 18-member panel needed 14 votes to send a 10-year plan to trim the debt to Congress for a vote. As his party’s then- ranking member on the House Budget Committee, Ryan led a bloc of three House Republicans who denied the additional votes needed. All three Senate Republicans on the panel backed the plan and one of them, former New Hampshire Senator Judd Gregg, said he believes the House Republicans who rejected it were beholden to an argument by anti-tax advocate Grover Norquist that the measure was tantamount to a tax increase.

Message.Title: Mitt messed up big time
Message.Msg: after 10 years of running for President you would think he would have learned something about politics by now, LOL This year, an incumbent even more embattled than George H.W. Bush has his own preferred election theme. He doesn't want to debate his own record, which is pretty dismal. He wants to debate the record of the congressional Republicans elected in 2010, a bunch radically less popular even than the president himself. You'd imagine that Romney's job was to refuse the Democratic invitation, to choose his own ground for the election, and to keep his distance from the congressional GOP. You'd imagine, but you'd be wrong. Romney has instead chosen to bolt himself to the House Republicans. He has chosen as his running mate Paul Ryan, the House Republican leader -- not their formal leader, but their intellectual leader, the person who set their agenda. He has effectively adopted Paul Ryan's agenda as his own: big immediate cuts in spending, a dramatic cut in the top rate of income tax to 28% and a bold reform of Medicare for those 55 and under. Obama's message in 2012: "Forget the economy. It's Medicare, stupid!" The Romney-Ryan response? "We agree. Medicare it is."

Topic.Title: Romney/Ryan---Women & Farmers (no clue)

Message.Msg: A new five-year Farm Bill including programs providing a safety net for farmers is stalled in the U.S. House of Representatives. The Senate passed one version of the bill but the House has failed to vote on its version. And the current bill expires in September. South Dakota Senator John Thune believes there will be pressure to pass it when Congress returns to Washington after Labor Day. "I think after having been out in the month of August a lot of members of Congress are going to have heard from their constituents about the drought conditions, how important it is that they get a new Farm Bill and hopefully that will change the political dynamic when we get back in September and there will be more votes for it," Thune said. Once the House passes its version, leaders from the House and the Senate need to come together to hammer out a final bill.

Message.Title: Ryan costs Mitt FLA and the election
Message.Msg: the elderly aren't as stupid as the GOP thinks Mitt Romney’s selection of Paul Ryan provides an opening for a fundamental debate over entitlements and health care policy. But is Romney ready for that debate? Campaigning this week, the former Massachusetts governor is already downplaying the one thing that made Ryan famous: His plan to severely cut health care and social spending. On Monday, Romney didn’t bring his new running mate to Florida, an elderly swing state where Medicare is about as popular as sunlight. (A whopping 74% of seniors oppose Ryan’s cuts to the program, according to CNN polling.) Instead, Romney brought chutzpah, telling Floridians that if they look at his health care plan and the Ryan budget, both actually enlarge Medicare. Who knew? “My plan, like [Ryan’s], really expands Medicare Advantage,” Romney said. It’s one thing to run on cutting health care for seniors because the debt and deficit are large. It’s another thing to run on the opposite pledge — expanding care — with the same plan to cut health care once in office. (At least Paul Ryan is direct.) We’ll come back to this campaign pitch in a moment. But first, why is Romney even talking about expanding government health care? It is because he’s now stuck between two inexorable laws in today’s politics: You can’t sell Medicare cuts to seniors, and you can’t beat President Obama without them.

Topic.Title: Ryan costs Mitt FLA and the election

Message.Msg: No cuts to Medicare enrollee services, though. Ask ANY senior about that. In fact, because of Obamacare: (1) seniors now have no deductible/copay for most screening and preventive care services; (2) the much-discussed "donut hole" in Medicare Part D, which required many seniors - about 4 million souls, and especially those needing multiple medications - to pay thousands of dollars out of pocket each year, has been ~50% closed under Obamacare so far, and will be closed further each year, disappearing entirely in 2020; (3) seniors (and the rest of us) can no longer be denied coverage due to "pre-existing conditions"; (4) seniors (and the rest of us) can no longer be subject to annual or lifetime coverage caps that leave them suddenly without coverage during a major illness; (5) seniors (and the rest of us) can no longer suddenly have coverage canceled for contrived, bullshyt reasons when insurance company death panels and accountants determine that costs of future coverage are likely to exceed premium payments; (6) seniors (and the rest of us) now have a guaranteed right of appeal when insurance company death panels and accountants make arbitrary and/or factually incorrect/unsupported denials of coverage for specific treatments and procedures. The "cuts" (so-called) to which you refer came overwhelmingly from: (a) eliminating the windfall subsidy to insurance companies offering "Medicare Advantage" plans, which provided them with a large guaranteed government-subsidized profit (~15% on average, year after year after year) for every such plan subscription sold; and (b) eliminating unnecessary/ duplicative services/ procedures, double-billing, up-coding, code-jamming, unbundling and other shady (fraudulent or bordering on fraudulent) provider practices (... you know, all that "waste, fraud and abuse" you CONs always complain about, but are often found at the center of ...).

Message.Msg: compare that to Ryan's plans Therein lies the rub. Ryan’s budget isn’t courageous — it’s just cruel. Three-fifths of the cuts he wants would hit those with low incomes, while those who have the most would continue getting more. It’s no wonder the former altar boy has had his knuckles rapped by a group of nuns for peddling a budget that “rejects church teaching about solidarity, inequality, the choice for the poor, and the common good.” Ryan’s claim to courage — beating up on the poor notwithstanding — lies in his supposed willingness to tackle tough fiscal issues without obfuscation or sugar-coating. This would be admirable – if it were not utter nonsense. He preaches the need for austerity while refusing to touch defense spending. He doesn’t specify which tax loopholes would be eliminated to pay for massive tax cuts. He voted against stimulus to help the whole country, but for the auto bailout to help his own congressional district. Still, it’s true that on pages 44-47 of Ryan’s so-called “Path to Prosperity” plan, you can read exactly what he intends to do with Medicare. Pages 50-54 explain his plans for tax reform. There are giant gimmicks and plenty is left unsaid, of course. But, yes, technically it is a plan, outlined in black and white and illustrated with colorful graphs and charts. Is that courageous? Not on the level of, say, our returning veterans, for whom Ryan’s budget would slash support by 13 percent. No, he is remarkable only because — unlike the man at the top of the ticket, who is a shameless cipher — Ryan isn’t hiding the ball. Instead, he#$%$ struggling Americans in the face with it.

Message.Title: Reagan Budget Director: Paul Ryan’s Plan Is A “Fairy Tale”

Message.Msg: Ryan, the House Budget Committee chairman, is the architect of a fiscal plan that includes steep spending cuts and the eventual transformation of Medicare into a federal subsidy for private coverage. Ryan’s plan wouldn’t affect current recipients or those 55 years and older. Future Generations Democrats say Ryan’s proposal would amount to scrapping Medicare for future generations, and that it would increase costs or reduce benefits for many seniors

Message.Title: the baggers are very good
Message.Msg: at picking on the poor and disabled, Romney intends to get his henchmen to hold them down while he cuts their hair off, but it's all in good fun Ryan’s proposal to cut Medicaid, the health-care program for the poor, would hit many seniors now. The program provides care to poor children, pregnant women, the disabled -- and some 6 million seniors who rely on it for nursing-home care, home health aides and other services. Medicaid Proposal Ryan’s budget would cut the program beginning next year, with the reductions totaling about $800 billion over the next decade. That’s about one-third of projected spending on the program. There’s a double standard when it comes to protecting Medicare and Medicaid beneficiaries from cuts, said Howard Gleckman, a resident fellow at the Washington-based Urban Institute. That’s because Medicaid beneficiaries are much poorer, and the program tends to be less well understood, he said. “The very poor, frail elderly aren’t very good at lobbying for themselves, and neither are their family members, and it’s very easy to forget about these people,” Gleckman said.

Topic.Title: Ryan costs Mitt FLA and the election

Message.Msg: Campaigning this week, the former Massachusetts governor is already downplaying the one thing that made Ryan famous: His plan to severely cut health care and social spending. On Monday, Romney didn’t bring his new running mate to Florida, an elderly swing state where Medicare is about as popular as sunlight. (A whopping 74% of seniors oppose Ryan’s cuts to the program, according to CNN polling.) Instead, Romney brought chutzpah, telling Floridians that if they look at his health care plan and the Ryan budget, both actually enlarge Medicare. Who knew? “My plan, like [Ryan’s], really expands Medicare Advantage,” Romney said. It’s one thing to run on cutting health care for seniors because the debt and deficit are large. It’s another thing to run on the opposite pledge — expanding care — with the same plan to cut health care once in office. (At least Paul Ryan is direct.) The WH didn't cut a penny from medicare enrollees, he is cutting 700 billion in fraud and insurance waste which he reinvests into healthcare programs. Ryan's budget calls for the exact same 700 billion in fraud and insurance waste cuts but in his case the savings go for tax cuts for millionaires. I know voters are stupid but I don't think they are as stupid as Romney is playing them. Sure there are some like you that are stupid enough to believe Romney but those of us not in the alternate reality teabagger rabbit hole know better

Message.Msg: The Democrat had earlier declared that he wouldn't be running for re-election in 2012. First elected to serve the 18th Congressional District in 2002, Cardoza would have faced the prospect of a bruising primary against strong Democratic candidates in order to prolong his political career. In announcing his resignation plans last year, he blasted the Obama administration for its "failure to understand and effectively address the current housing foreclosure crisis." Cardoza's seat will be vacated effective midnight on Wednesday, but no special election will be held due to the timing of his resignation.
